quote: You're sure I can't interest you in    some Yigrish cream pie.
Thank you, Doctor, but I'm quite    full.
You barely touched your food.
The truth is, I've been trying to    lose a little weight.  Hemming women's    dresses may provide me with a modest    income, but it doesn't offer much in    the way of exercise.
If you'd like, I could help you set    up an exercise program in one of the    holosuites.
I might take you up on that.  But    speaking of holosuites...
Happy Birthday.  I know it's a few    days off, but I wanted to give you    your present early.
Thank you, Garak.
It's a Cardassian holosuite program.     An adaptation of one of Shoggoth's    enigma tales.
I see.
You sound disappointed.  I thought    you liked mystery novels.
I do.  Human mystery novels.  The    problem with Cardassian enigma tales    is that they all end the same way.     All the suspects are always guilty.
Yes, but the challenge comes from    determining exactly who is guilty of    what.       Is Lieutenant Dax throwing you another    "surprise" party this year?
So I'm told.
You don't seem very enthused about    it.
It's not that I don't appreciate all    the trouble she goes to.  But the    thing of it is... this year's a little    different.
How so?
This will be my thirtieth birthday.
And?
You know, Garak, sometimes I forget    you're not human.
It's an important thing to keep in    mind, Doctor.
Well, in many human cultures, the    thirtieth birthday is considered a    sort of milestone.  It marks the end    of youth and the beginning of the    slow march into middle age.
And that's... considered bad?
No.  It's just that... once you hit    thirty, it becomes harder and harder    to ignore the passage of time.
Doctor, are you trying to say that    you're afraid of growing old.
Of course not.  It's nothing to do    with fear.  I'm just having a    little... difficulty accepting the    aging process.
I wasn't aware that humans saw growing    old as a negative experience.  On    Cardassia, advanced age is seen as a    sign of power and dignity.

I'm well aware that aging is part of    the natural cycle of life.  I just    don't want to be reminded of it.       Look, Garak, the fact is, in two    days I turn thirty, and if I want to    be grumpy about it, that's my    prerogative.
By all means, Doctor, be as grumpy    as you want.
I appreciate the support.
Excuse me, Doctor.  Do you have a    moment?
What can I do for you, Quark?

Uh... my friend... Altovar here is    looking to purchase a small quantity    of...       Bio-memetic gel.  And I was wondering    if you might know how he could obtain,    let's say, a few hundred milliliters.
Bio-memetic gel is a restricted    substance.  Its sale is strictly    forbidden by Federation law.
I thought so.       You see.  I told you.
I'm willing to pay whatever's    necessary.  Name your price.
Why do you need it?
That's my business.
I'm sorry, but Bio-memetic gel can    be very hazardous if not handled    correctly.  It's not for sale.  At    any price.
Well, we tried.  Thank you, Doctor.
Quark, you should warn your friend    that even attempting to obtain Bio-   memetic gel is a felony under    Federation law.
I know.  I told him that.  But he    insisted that I ask you anyway.     Letheans can be incredibly stubborn.       I hope you'll forgive the    interruption.
You know, we just introduced a new    lunch menu at the bar.
Good-bye, Quark.
Don't take it personally.       He's turning thirty.
Julian.  What's new?
Dax, if you're trying to find out if    I know about my "surprise party"    Chief O'Brien has already told me    about it.
He did?  That does it.  That's the    last surprise party I let him help    me plan.  Every year he insists on    being involved, and every year he    manages to spoil the surprise.
The chief's a man of many talents,    but keeping a secret isn't one of    them.

Well now that you know about it, you    may as well help with the final    details.  We've narrowed the choices    down to two different holosuite    programs.  Would you rather have    your party at a Greek palace on Mount    Olympus or at Louis Pasteur's house    in Paris?  Or as Quark put it, wood    nymphs or can-can girls?
I'm going to have to think about    that one.
Of course there's always game seven    of the nineteen sixty-four World    Series.
Let me guess... Commander Sisko's    idea.
He says that's one of the greatest    baseball games of all time.
If you care about that sort of thing.       So why don't we say...       Wood nymphs.
I knew it.  I'll tell Quark first    thing in the morning.       Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to    have a little chat with Chief O'Brien.
It's pretty late.  He's probably    asleep.
Good.  I'll wake him.
Lights.
What do you think you're doing?
Bashir to Security.       Bashir to Ops.       This is Doctor Bashir.  Is anyone    reading me?       Computer, locate Commander Sisko.       Computer, please respond... Computer?
Hello?
Is someone there?
Hello?  Is anybody here?
Where is everyone?
Who's there?
Quark?
It's all right.  It's me.  Bashir.
What is it?  What's going on?  Tell    me.
He's going to kill us.  He's going    to kill us all.
Who?  Who are you so afraid of?    (off Quark's frightened     look)   Where's Sisko?  What happened to the    rest of the crew?
Look, why don't you come with me?     We'll go try to find them.
No.  Don't you see.  If we move,    he'll find us.  But if we stay here,    we might be safe.
Safe from whom?       Quark, you have to tell me.
He's here.
We've got to get these lights back    on.
It's too late.  He's found us.  We've    got to get out.
Wait.
Who's there?  Show yourself.
Quark?  Quark!
Tarkalean Tea?
Constable?
Garak?
What are you doing here, Doctor?
I was about to ask you the same thing.
I was looking for Constable Odo.     Everyone on this station seems to    have disappeared.
Not everyone.  I just saw Quark.  He    was cowering behind his bar.  He    thinks someone is terrorizing the    station.  And I'm not sure I disagree    with him.
What do you mean?  Tell me what's    going on.
There was some... thing in Quark's...    tearing up the place.  I never got a    good look at it, but believe me, it    wasn't friendly.
Computer.

It's no use.  As far as I can tell,    the station's suffered some kind of    massive systems failure.  Aside from    life support, and simple functions    like turbolifts and doors, nothing    seems to be working.  It's been like    this for hours.  I was up late    programming some replicator patterns    for a suit I'm designing, and    everything just went dead.
I can't believe that you, Quark and    I are the only people left on the    station.  Sisko and the others must    be here somewhere.
Maybe.  Or maybe they've fallen victim    to some kind of rampant virus, or    space anomaly, or Dominion plot.
All the more reason to try to locate    them.
Wait.  Do you hear that?
Hear what?
That sound.  It's like voices    whispering.
I don't hear anything.  But then    Cardassian hearing isn't quite as    acute as human's.       Doctor, are you feeling all right?     You look... different somehow.
What is it?
Your hair.  It seems to be turning    gray.
So I've noticed.
I guess you had reason to worry about    turning thirty after all.  Either    that, or your job is more stressful    than I thought.
Look, Garak, we don't have time for    this.  We have to find out what's    going on here.
I agree.  Maybe we should split up.     I can search the Docking Ring while    you look around the Habitat Ring and    the Central Core.
We'll meet back on the Promenade in    an hour.       Be careful.
You, too.       And Doctor, try to relax.
Level H-One, Section "A."
Altovar.
Look, what are we doing standing    around here?
What do you want to do?  Rush out    and get us all killed?
It's better than doing nothing.     Let's go.
Of course.  And follow you right    into a trap.  Is that what you want?
You're all crazy.  None of this is    helping us deal with the Lethean.
I say we don't do anything until we    get reinforcements from Bajor.
Julian.  There you are.    Bajor.  Bajor doesn't even  Where have you been?   know we're in trouble.
Looking for you.            And we can't tell them unless        you can get the communications        system back on-line.
And we can't tell them unless        you can get the communications        system back on-line.

character: And we can't tell them unless
quote: you can get the communications        system back on-line.
system back on-line.

Well, I'm glad you're here.          It'll take hours.  There's too        many system's sabotaged... My        work crews are all missing... I        can't manufacture any new parts        until we get the replicators fixed...
many system's sabotaged... My        work crews are all missing... I        can't manufacture any new parts        until we get the replicators fixed...
work crews are all missing... I        can't manufacture any new parts        until we get the replicators fixed...

character: work crews are all missing... I
quote: can't manufacture any new parts        until we get the replicators fixed...
until we get the replicators fixed...
The first thing we have to do is    neutralize the Lethean.
The Lethean?  You mean Altovar?
You know him?
We've met.  He attacked me in the    Infirmary.
And now he's trying to kill us all    by destroying the station.
What are we waiting for?  Let's get    some phasers and hunt him down.
If you ask me, none of us will be    safe until he's dead.
If we go out looking for the Lethean,    we're the ones who'll end up dead.
Tell you what, while we're looking    for the Lethean, maybe we can find    your backbone.
Maybe he doesn't want us to find the    Lethean.  Maybe he's in league with    him.
All right, that's enough.       Computer, scan the occupants of this    room for any anomalous readings.
Doctor, what are you doing?
You're all acting very strangely and    I intend to find out why.       Computer?
Don't bother, Doctor.       For some reason, the computer doesn't    seem to be working.
Don't go blaming me, Constable.     None of this would've happened if    Security had been doing its job.

Look, I said, that's enough.       Where's Sisko?  Where are O'Brien's    work crews?  I've been wandering    around for hours and the only people    I've seen are Quark and Garak.     Where's everyone else?  There's    something very wrong here.
I'll say there is.  Have you looked    in the mirror lately?
What are you talking about?
You're face.  You look... older.
If you're referring to my hair, I'm    already aware--
It's more than that.  You've got    wrinkles.
Hold on... Does anyone else hear    that?
What?
I don't hear anything.
Garak didn't either.
Julian, what are you talking about?
I know it sounds strange, but I keep    hearing voices.
And he says we're acting peculiar.
So what are these so-called voices    saying?
That's the problem.  I can't make    out the words.
I think you're the one who needs    help, Doctor.  Not us.
Maybe you should lie down.
I'm fine.
Except that you're hearing voices    and you seem to have aged twenty-   five years in the last few hours.
There has to be a logical explanation    for this... maybe some kind of    virus... or a subspace anomaly...       A neural inversion field... anaphasic    parasites...
Keep thinking, Julian.  While you    try to figure it out, I'm going to    find the Lethean and stop him before    he sabotages any more systems.
What good will that do?  You don't    have any idea where he is.  We don't    even know what we're up against.     How strong is he?  Can he be hurt by    phaser fire?
Don't worry Chief.  I'm not asking    for any help from you.  If he's here,    I'll find him.  Even if I have to do    it by myself.

Dax, settle down.  You're not going    anywhere.  Not yet, anyway.  There    are too many strange things going on    here.  My aging, the missing    crewmembers, the sabotage to the    station, your abnormal behavior.
You think it's all connected    somehow?
I think we need to find out.       Chief, is there any way to get the    internal sensors on-line?
There's a computer processing junction    not far from here.  I might be able    to repair the internal sensors from    there.       But I'm not going alone.
What a surprise.
Don't worry.  I'm not letting you    out of my sight.
We'll all go together.  Let's get    moving.

It's even worse than I thought.  The    entire sensor array is burnt out and    there's extensive damage to the    computer's central processor.  The    only system that looks salvageable    is the subspace communication relay.
That would at least let us contact    Bajor.
See what you can do, Chief.
Constable, would you stop doing that?
Doing what?
Looking around like that.  It's    getting on my nerves.
There's no harm in keeping both eyes    open.
I don't remember asking for your    opinion.
If the Lethean's around, I want to    know it.
The last time I saw him, he was in    the Central Core.
(as they continue to     work)   The Central Core?  What level were    you on?
Level Five.  But I doubt he's still    there.  I think I lost him.
You think?
Just keep working, Chief.
For all we know, he could be right    outside the door.
And if he is, then you'll have led    him here.
That's fine with me, I'd just as    soon finish this here and now.
Hold on Lieutenant, I think I've got    the communications relay working.
Open hailing frequencies.  Try to    contact Bajor.
It's not working.  I still can't    transmit.  But I'm receiving a signal.     Audio only.
Let's hear it.
... four CC's of cordrazine, but there    was no response.
It sounds like you, Lieutenant.
There has to be something we can do.
That's Sisko's voice.
We've tried everything we can think    of, but we haven't been able to    counteract the telepathic damage.
Where's this signal coming from?
I don't know.  Somewhere outside the    station.
Give me the bottom line.
The bottom line is that Julian's in    some kind of telepathically induced    coma.  And unless we can get him out    of it he'll be dead in less than    three hours.
I'll be in my office.  Keep me    informed.
Don't give up, Julian.  Please.     You'll pull through.  I know you    will.
What the hell is going on here?
Delta waves.       When I scan myself for brain activity,    all I get are low frequency delta    waves.
And what's that supposed to mean?
It means those voices were telling    the truth.
I'm in a coma.
How can you stand there and say that    you're in a coma?  That's crazy.
Not necessarily, Major.
I suppose the next thing your going    to tell us is that we're unconscious    too.
Not according to these readings.
I'm glad to hear it.
Actually, I'm not picking up any    life signs from you at all.
Let me see that.
You want to know what this means?     It means this tricorder's broken,    that's all.
I don't think so.
What are you saying, Doctor?  That    we don't exist?
I've had enough of this.  I'm not    some figment of your imagination.
But don't you see, that explains why    you've all been behaving so strangely.
I'm not behaving strangely.       Am I?
You all are.  Dax isn't the kind of    person who solves her problems by    running around with a phaser.  Chief,    you're not usually so pessimistic.
This is a waste of time.  That Lethean    could be here any minute.
So if you're in a coma, and we're    not real, then what are we doing    here?
Maybe we're just here to give him    someone to talk to.
A paranoid, a coward, a hothead,    and... me?  You'd think he'd pick    better company.
I haven't picked anyone.  I'm in a    coma.  I'm the only one who's really    here.
Which means when I talk to you, I'm    really just talking to myself.
I wish you'd stop saying that.
But there's no other possible    explanation.
So you're saying that I'm you?
In a manner of speaking.
And I suppose he's you, too?
All of you are.  It's like you each    embody a different aspect of my    personality... a different voice in    my head.
I don't believe we're having this    discussion.
If I had to guess, I'd say you    represent doubt and disbelief.
I do not.

I knew you'd say that.       Major, you're the perfect choice to    represent my aggression.  Odo, you    embody my suspicions and fears.  And    Dax... to me you've always represented    confidence and a sense of adventure.
Thank you, Julian.
You're forgetting something, Doctor.     What about the Lethean?  What's he    supposed to represent?
I suppose he represents the telepathic    damage that the real Lethean did to    my mind.
So why is this Lethean running around    sabotaging the station?

It's not the station he's sabotaging.       It's my mind.  The station represents    my mind.  Just like you represent    aspects of my personality.       Think about it... when Chief O'Brien    fixed the communications relay, we    were able to hear what was happening    in the real world.
It's like he restored your hearing.
Exactly.  So maybe if we can repair    the station...
You'd wake up.
Yeah?  And if you wake up, what    happens to us?
Julian.
Jadzia!
Jadzia, Jadzia.
Ready, Doctor?
How did I get here?
Don't ask me.  After all, we're in    your mind.       It's a shame about Lieutenant Dax.
How'd you know about that?
I'm part of you, remember?  I know    what you know.  Maybe even a little    more.
Still the man of mystery?
You wouldn't have me any other way.
I think I'm getting a little too old    for this.
Apparently so.  You, or should I say    "we," are running out of time.       Your serve, Doctor.
I can't stay here.  I've got to get    the main computer back on line.
Then you'd better get to Ops.  If    repairs are to be done, that's the    place to do them.
You're right.  You try to find Odo,    O'Brien and Kira.  Tell them to meet    me in Ops.
I'd be delighted.  I wonder if any    of them plays tennis.
Help us... Doctor... Help... We need    you...

quote: I suppose you're right.       Take care of things here.  I won't    be long.       All right, let's--
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: You're staying right here, trapped    on this station, watching while I    destroy you piece by piece.  And    when all the best parts of you are    gone, when there's nothing left but    a withered shell, then, and only    then, will I put you out of your    misery.
scene: 33   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

Doctor...
Odo, what happened?
The Lethean.  He came out of nowhere.
He's trying to rob me of my    confidence, my strength, my    intelligence... I've got to get to    Ops while I still can.
Use the maintenance conduits.  They're    your best chance.
Chief.

quote: How did we get back here?
You tell me.  It's your mind.
These monitors... they're displaying    my vital signs.
What's the prognosis?
Pulse is thready... blood pressure    dropping steadily... I'm dying.
I could've told you that just by    looking at you.
The kidneys... the heart... brain    hemorrhage... one hour... fifteen    minutes...
Can I offer you gentlemen a drink?
Quark, where did all these people    come from?
Just goes to show you... give the    people what they want, and they'll    show up in droves.       Now... care to place a wager.
A wager?  On what?
You name it... On how much longer    you've got to live... What organ    will fail first... ultimate cause of    death.  The house is covering all    bets.
What if I want to bet that I'll    survive?
It's a longshot, but if you want to    throw your money away, who am I to    stop you?
Dabo!
Oh-oh.  Looks like all bets are off.
Including the house.
Garak.  The Lethean.  He's in Quark's.
He hasn't caught you yet, Doctor.     Let's get you out of here.
No.  I've got to go to Ops.
What's wrong?
I don't believe this.  I've broken    my hip.  I can't walk.
Well, Doctor, it was a good game    while it lasted.
I've got to keep moving.
And how do you propose to do that?
You're going to help me.

Doctor, I admire your tenacity, but    I'm afraid it's over.  Look at    yourself.  Your bones are as brittle    as twigs, you can barely catch your    breath, and you can't even stand,    let alone walk.
But other than that, I feel wonderful.     Now are you going to give me a hand    or not?
It would be a privilege.  Now what    would you like me to do?
Help me up.
Of course.
Anyone home?
Surprise!
What's all this?
"Happy Birthday, Dear Julian... "
"Happy Birthday to you."
"And many more."       Doctor, I really must congratulate    you.  You have a fascinating mind.
Look, I'm sorry, but I don't have    time for this.
But it's a party.  And it's all for    you.
You should try to enjoy yourself.     It's your birthday.
Garak, get me over to the engineering    station.  Now.
Sorry, my dear.
There has to be a way to reactivate    the station's central computer    network.
Any ideas on how to go about doing    that?

My Engineering extension classes at    Starfleet Medical focused mainly on    starship operations, but I think if    I can re-route the primary command    processor to bypass the disabled    systems, I should be able to get it    operational.
So which panel accesses the computer?
If you were really Garak, you could    tell me.  In fact, you could probably    fix this computer without my help.
But I'm not really Garak, am I?  I'm    just another part of you.
Help me get this panel off.
Tennis balls?
This station is in worse shape then    we thought.
Garak...    (holds out his hand     for help)   One of these panels has to have the    computer controls behind it.  I just    have to find the right one.
(doesn't move to help     him)   Face it, Doctor, there's no way to    repair the damage.  It's too    extensive.
If you won't help me, I'll do it    myself.
I'd be more than willing to help, if    I thought it would accomplish    anything, but you're only delaying    the inevitable.
That doesn't sound like the Garak I    know.
Doctor, we've been through this.     I'm not Garak.  I'm you.
It doesn't sound like me either.

I've been thinking... Why has the    Lethean let you live?  He killed    everyone else who could've helped    me.  And exactly what part of me are    you supposed to represent?  My    conscience, my curiosity, my sense    of humor?
You tell me.
I don't think you're any part of me.     In fact, I don't think you belong    here at all.
So that leaves me with one question.     Who are you?
You've put up an entertaining    struggle, Doctor.
I'm glad you're enjoying yourself.
But now it's time for you to make    things easy on yourself.
You mean just give up?  I don't think    so.
Why not?  Isn't that what you've    always done?       Remember, Doctor, I'm inside your    head.  I know all about you.
When you were younger, you wanted to    be a tennis player, didn't you?
I wasn't good enough to play    professionally.
You can't lie to me.  Not in here.     You were good enough.  But you knew    your parents wouldn't approve.  So    you gave up.  And became a doctor    instead.
I love medicine.
But you loved tennis more.       And what about medical school?  You    should've been first in your class,    what went wrong?
I made a mistake on the final exam.
You mistook a pre-ganglionic fiber    for a post-ganglionic nerve.
That's right.
But pre-ganglionic fibers and post-   ganglionic nerves aren't anything    alike.  Any first year medical student    can tell them apart.       You purposely gave the wrong answer.
That's ridiculous.
You didn't want to be number one in    your class.  You couldn't take the    pressure.
That's not true.
Isn't it?       Then let's talk about Lieutenant    Dax.  You like her, don't you?
Dax is my friend.
She could've been more if you'd tried    a little harder.  But you'd rather    give up than fight, wouldn't you?
We'll see about that.
Wait.  Where are you going?
What do you think you're doing?
The mistake I made was trying to    repair the station from Ops.  That    may be the nerve center of the real    station, but this...    (indicates the     Infirmary)   Is the center of my world.
Get away from that panel.
(begins working on     the cables)   Or what?  You'll kill me.  Go ahead.     What's stopping you?  You've had    plenty of chances.  It must not be    as easy for you as you make it sound.
That's better.       You know, you don't look half as    threatening in normal light.
Take a close look, Doctor.  You're    dying.  Why can't you just accept    it?

Because that's what you want me to    do.  You may be inside my head, but    you don't understand me nearly as    well as you think you do.  Take Dax...       I do have feelings for her, but the    important thing is... she's my friend.     And I wouldn't trade that friendship    for anything.  And as far as my career    is concerned... I may have been a    good tennis player, but I'm a great    doctor.  Maybe I could've been first    in my class, but it wouldn't have    made any difference in my life.  I    still would've chosen this assignment.     This is where I belong.       Computer activate quarantine field    three-Jay.
You can't do this.
I can do anything I want.  It's my    mind.       Begin sterilization.
Noooooooo.
Julian... He's awake.
Vital signs have stabilized.  His    brain wave activity's normal.
Welcome back, Doctor.
You'll never believe where I've been.
As for the real Altovar, he triggered    a security alert when he broke into    the Infirmary.  He barely got two    meters before Odo arrested him.
It sounds like he was a lot more    dangerous in your mind than he was    in the real world.
Actually, I did some checking on    Letheans.  Their telepathic attacks    are almost always fatal.  I guess I    was lucky.
Cardassians don't believe in luck,    Doctor.  You survived because you    were strong.
I didn't feel strong.       One thing's for sure, after    experiencing life at the age of a    hundred plus, turning thirty doesn't    seem so bad anymore.

In that case, Happy Birthday.       You know, Doctor, the thing I find    most fascinating about this entire    incident is how your unconscious    mind chose people you know to    represent the various parts of your    personality.
It did make things interesting.
What I find interesting is how your    mind ended up casting me in the role    of the villain.
I wouldn't read too much into that,    Garak.
How can I not?  To think, after all    this time, all our lunches together...    you still don't trust me.
There's hope for you yet, Doctor.
